overview: A 36-week Algebra 2 course built on a 10-unit scope and sequence. Extends algebraic reasoning through advanced functions, polynomial and rational analysis, exponential and logarithmic modeling, trigonometry foundations, probability and statistics, and cumulative cross-domain modeling. Spiral review threads (factoring, domain checks, function notation, algebra fluency, modeling) are woven throughout every unit.
naturalProgression: Begin with Boot Camp Review (Unit 0) to diagnose and fill gaps from Algebra 1 before new content
Build linear systems and introduce matrices (Unit 1) as tools for multi-variable problem solving
Deep dive into quadratics (Unit 2) with all forms, all methods, complex numbers, and the 'which method?' decision
Extend to polynomial functions (Unit 3) with advanced factoring, division theorems, and graphing behavior
Master rational expressions and functions (Unit 4) with asymptotic analysis and domain awareness
Develop exponential and logarithmic reasoning (Unit 5) as inverse function pairs with real-world modeling
Simplify radical expressions and solve radical equations (Unit 6) with extraneous solution checks
Discover patterns in sequences and series (Unit 7) with financial applications and convergence
Establish trigonometry foundations (Unit 8) from unit circle through sinusoidal graphing and trig equations
Apply counting, probability, and normal distribution concepts (Unit 9) bridging algebra to statistics
Synthesize all skills through cumulative modeling and a final mastery assessment (Unit 10)
spiralReviewThreads: Factoring fluency — maintained from Unit 2 onward through warm-ups and checkpoint spiral problems
Solving with domain checks — reinforced in rational, logarithmic, radical, and trig equation solving
Function notation and composition — applied across all function families throughout the course
Algebra fluency — multi-step equation solving embedded in every unit's independent practice
Mathematical modeling — real-world problem contexts integrated progressively from Unit 1 through Unit 10

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies. The AI chooses HOW to introduce based on the student's learning style.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery and explains using the student's preferred style (visual, verbal, step-by-step, etc.).
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. The AI asks 1-2 targeted questions to verify the student grasps the concept, not just the procedure. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. The AI provides problems and supports the student through them, offering hints ONLY when needed. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding. The AI decides when to move on.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. The AI checks how the student FEELS about the material—not just accuracy. Adjusts pacing and tone based on anxiety, confidence, and engagement signals.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. The AI presents problems and steps back, allowing the student to work independently. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck. The AI evaluates accuracy, independence, and transfer.

Formal assessment for skill mastery. The AI determines if the student has met the 4-Pillar mastery criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention). Awards mastery or identifies areas for re-teaching.

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, numerical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and anxiety level

modules.title: Boot Camp Review
modules.preview: Diagnose and fill Algebra 1 gaps before new content
essentialQuestions: Which Algebra 1 skills are secure and which need reinforcement before Algebra 2?
How does function notation connect to evaluating and composing relationships?
Why is factoring the single most important algebraic manipulation skill?

lessons.title: Linear Equations & Inequalities Review
lessons.teachingNotes: Diagnostic-first: assess before reteaching. Skip secure skills.

lessons.title: Function Notation & Evaluation
lessons.teachingNotes: Critical foundation for entire course. Ensure automatic fluency.

lessons.title: Exponent Rules & Factoring Review
lessons.teachingNotes: Factoring fluency is non-negotiable. Students who struggle here will struggle everywhere.

lessons.title: Graphing Lines & Slope Review
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to upcoming systems unit. Slope as rate of change.

modules.title: Unit 0 Diagnostic Checkpoint
modules.preview: Assess readiness for Algebra 2 content

modules.title: Linear Systems & Matrices
modules.preview: Substitution, elimination, modeling, matrix operations
essentialQuestions: When is substitution more efficient than elimination, and vice versa?
How do systems of inequalities define feasible regions in real-world optimization?
How do matrices provide a systematic approach to solving systems?

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Substitution
lessons.teachingNotes: Emphasize when substitution is the natural choice (one variable already isolated).

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Elimination
concepts: Adding/subtracting equations to eliminate a variable
lessons.teachingNotes: Show how elimination scales to 3-variable systems more naturally than substitution.

lessons.title: Systems of Inequalities & Modeling
lessons.teachingNotes: Real-world context: business, chemistry, optimization.

lessons.title: Matrix Operations & Inverse Matrices
lessons.teachingNotes: Introduce matrices as organized data structures, then as equation-solving tools.

modules.title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Linear Systems & Matrices
modules.preview: Assess systems solving and matrix skills

modules.title: Quadratics Deep Dive
modules.preview: All forms, all methods, complex numbers, discriminant
essentialQuestions: How do standard, vertex, and factored form each reveal different information about a quadratic?
How does the 'which method?' decision develop algebraic reasoning?
Why do complex numbers exist and what do they mean geometrically?

lessons.title: Three Forms of a Quadratic
lessons.teachingNotes: Each form answers a different question: standard → y-intercept, vertex → min/max, factored → zeros.

lessons.title: Solving Quadratics: All Methods
lessons.teachingNotes: The 'which method?' question is the real skill. Build decision-making, not just execution.

lessons.title: Complex Numbers & the Discriminant
lessons.teachingNotes: Motivate complex numbers through quadratics with negative discriminant.

lessons.title: Transformations & Quadratic Modeling
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect abstract transformations to concrete real-world modeling.

modules.title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Quadratics Deep Dive
modules.preview: Assess quadratic mastery across all methods and representations

modules.title: Polynomial Functions
modules.preview: Operations, advanced factoring, division theorems, graphing
essentialQuestions: How does factoring by grouping and sum/difference of cubes extend basic factoring?
How do the Remainder and Factor Theorems connect evaluation, division, and factoring?
How does a polynomial's equation determine its end behavior and graph shape?

lessons.title: Polynomial Operations
lessons.teachingNotes: Foundation for all polynomial manipulation that follows.

lessons.title: Advanced Factoring Techniques
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the highest-leverage factoring content. Students must be fluent here.

lessons.title: Long Division & Synthetic Division
lessons.teachingNotes: Parallel to numeric long division. Synthetic division is a powerful shortcut.

lessons.title: Graphing Polynomial Functions
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect algebraic structure to graphical behavior systematically.

modules.title: Unit 3 Checkpoint: Polynomial Functions
modules.preview: Assess polynomial operations, factoring, division, and graphing

modules.title: Rational Expressions & Functions
modules.preview: Simplify, operate, solve rational equations, graph with asymptotes
essentialQuestions: Why must we factor before canceling, and what distinguishes factors from terms?
How do vertical asymptotes, horizontal asymptotes, and holes arise from algebraic structure?
Why do rational equations sometimes produce extraneous solutions?

lessons.title: Simplifying Rational Expressions
lessons.teachingNotes: Emphasize: cancel FACTORS, not terms.

lessons.title: Operations with Rational Expressions
lessons.teachingNotes: Parallel to numeric fraction operations.

lessons.title: Solving Rational Equations
lessons.teachingNotes: Domain checking is critical — values that zero a denominator are excluded.

lessons.title: Graphing Rational Functions
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect algebraic features (factor structure) to graphical features (asymptotes, holes).

modules.title: Unit 4 Checkpoint: Rational Functions
modules.preview: Assess rational expression and function skills

modules.title: Exponential & Logarithmic Functions
modules.preview: Logarithm properties, exponential models, solving equations
essentialQuestions: How are exponential and logarithmic functions inverses of each other?
How do properties of logarithms simplify complex expressions and equations?
How do exponential models describe growth and decay in the real world?
Why must we always check the domain when solving logarithmic equations?

lessons.title: Exponential Growth & Decay
lessons.teachingNotes: Ground in concrete contexts first: money, populations, radioactive decay.

lessons.title: Introduction to Logarithms
lessons.teachingNotes: The bridge: log_b(x) = y ↔ b^y = x. Drill this conversion relentlessly.

lessons.title: Properties of Logarithms
lessons.teachingNotes: Mirror exponent rules explicitly. Build 'common errors' awareness.

lessons.title: Solving Exponential & Logarithmic Equations
concepts: Converting log equations to exponential form
lessons.teachingNotes: ALWAYS check domain as final step. Arguments of logarithms must be positive.

modules.title: Unit 5 Checkpoint: Exponential & Logarithmic
modules.preview: Assess exponential and logarithmic skills

modules.title: Radicals & Rational Exponents
modules.preview: Rational exponents, simplifying, radical equations
essentialQuestions: How are radicals and rational exponents two notations for the same concept?
Why does squaring both sides of an equation sometimes create false solutions?
How do radical functions model real-world phenomena like pendulums and distances?

lessons.title: Rational Exponents
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to prior exponent rules. Rational exponents are not new — they're a natural extension.

lessons.title: Simplifying Radical Expressions with Variables
lessons.teachingNotes: Variable expressions add domain considerations. |x| vs x matters.

lessons.title: Solving Radical Equations
lessons.teachingNotes: Always show WHY squaring introduces extraneous solutions.

modules.title: Unit 6 Checkpoint: Radicals & Rational Exponents
modules.preview: Assess radical and rational exponent skills

modules.title: Sequences & Series
modules.preview: Arithmetic, geometric, sigma notation, infinite series, financial applications
essentialQuestions: How are arithmetic sequences connected to linear functions and geometric sequences to exponential?
What conditions determine whether an infinite series converges to a finite sum?
How do sequences and series model financial scenarios like loans and annuities?

lessons.title: Arithmetic Sequences & Series
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to linear functions: arithmetic sequence = linear graph. d = slope.

lessons.title: Geometric Sequences & Series
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to exponential functions: geometric sequence = exponential graph.

lessons.title: Sigma Notation & Financial Applications
lessons.teachingNotes: Financial applications give real-world relevance to geometric series formulas.

modules.title: Unit 7 Checkpoint: Sequences & Series
modules.preview: Assess sequence, series, and financial application skills

modules.title: Trigonometry Foundations
modules.preview: Unit circle, right triangle trig, graphing sinusoidal, trig equations
essentialQuestions: How does the unit circle unify all trigonometric function values?
How do amplitude, period, phase shift, and vertical shift transform sinusoidal graphs?
Why do most trig equations have multiple solutions in a given interval?

lessons.title: Angle Measurement: Degrees & Radians
lessons.teachingNotes: Radians are a ratio, not arbitrary. The formula s = rθ shows why radians are natural.

lessons.title: The Unit Circle & Trig Functions
concepts: (cos θ, sin θ) on the unit circle
lessons.teachingNotes: Only 5 key Q1 points + symmetry. Teach the pattern, not 16 separate facts.

lessons.title: Right Triangle Trig & Inverse Functions
concepts: Inverse trig functions and their restricted ranges
lessons.teachingNotes: Review from Geometry, extend with inverse trig and more complex applications.

lessons.title: Graphing Sinusoidal Functions
concepts: y = A sin(Bx + C) + D transformations
Real-world sinusoidal models (Ferris wheel, tides, temperature)
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect each parameter to a physical meaning. Amplitude = max displacement, period = one cycle.

lessons.title: Solving Trigonometric Equations
lessons.teachingNotes: Most equations have TWO solutions per period. Use reference angles + quadrant analysis.

modules.title: Unit 8 Checkpoint: Trigonometry Foundations
modules.preview: Assess trig fundamentals across all subtopics

modules.title: Probability & Statistics
modules.preview: Counting, probability rules, binomial probability, normal distribution
essentialQuestions: How does the Fundamental Counting Principle form the basis for permutations and combinations?
How does conditional probability change our assessment of event likelihood?
How does the normal distribution model real-world variability?

lessons.title: Counting Principles, Permutations & Combinations
lessons.teachingNotes: Build from concrete examples: outfits, menus, committees.

lessons.title: Probability Rules & Conditional Probability
lessons.teachingNotes: Mutually exclusive ≠ independent. This distinction is critical.

lessons.title: Binomial Probability
lessons.teachingNotes: Combine counting (C(n,k)) with probability. Applications: free throws, quality control.

lessons.title: Normal Distribution & Z-Scores
lessons.teachingNotes: Bridge to AP Statistics. Real-world: test scores, manufacturing, heights.

modules.title: Unit 9 Checkpoint: Probability & Statistics
modules.preview: Assess counting, probability, and statistics skills

modules.title: Cumulative Modeling & Review
modules.preview: Cross-unit integration, modeling decisions, course synthesis
essentialQuestions: Given a real-world scenario, how do you determine which function model fits and why?
How do the function families compare in their key features: domain, range, end behavior, rate of change?
How does integrating skills from multiple units prepare you for advanced mathematics?

lessons.title: Choosing the Right Function Model
concepts: Linear vs quadratic vs exponential vs logarithmic vs trigonometric
Data clues: first differences, second differences, constant ratios
lessons.teachingNotes: This is synthesis — students apply decision-making, not just computation.

lessons.title: Multi-Step Integration Problems
concepts: When do two models give the same value?
lessons.teachingNotes: Problems that don't announce which tools to use — the decision IS the skill.

lessons.title: Strategic Course Review
concepts: Targeted review based on checkpoint data
lessons.teachingNotes: Use diagnostic data to target individual gaps. Light review for strong areas.

modules.title: Algebra 2 Final Mastery Assessment
modules.preview: Comprehensive final exam covering all 10 units

aiGuidanceNotes: This Algebra 2 course follows a 36-week, 10-unit scope and sequence with spiral review threads woven throughout. The thread connecting everything is FUNCTIONS — every unit introduces or extends a function family with its own behavior, graph, and applications. Inverse relationships recur throughout (exponentials/logarithms, squaring/roots, functions/inverses). Five non-negotiable skill threads (factoring, domain checks, function notation, algebra fluency, modeling) are spiraled through warm-ups and checkpoint problems starting from the unit where they're introduced. The Boot Camp Review (Unit 0) is diagnostic-first — assess before reteaching, and skip secure skills. The Cumulative Modeling unit (Unit 10) is about synthesis and decision-making, not new content. The AI should use prior checkpoint data to personalize the review experience. Throughout the course, emphasize the 'which method?' and 'which model?' metacognitive skills over rote procedure execution.
